headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference is also available via the audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any obj
componenttext:
Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference is also available via the audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its annual reports on Form 10-K and our reported shareholders and the letter to shareholders, which has been posted on the company's website and will use this conference call to respond to questions. 
Acting as moderator for the call will be Julia Hornack. At this time, I'll turn the call over to Ms. Hornack.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; Trisha Griffith, our Personal Line Chief Financial Officer; and Bill Cody, our Chief Business Officer. The call is s
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; Trisha Griffith, our Personal Line Chief Financial Officer; and Bill Cody, our Chief Business Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour. 
As always, our discussions on this call may include forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to the many risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events and results to differ materially from those discussed during the call. Additional information concerning those risks and uncertainties is available in our 2015 annual report on Form 10-K where you will find discussions of the risk factors affecting our businesses, Safe Harbor statements related to forward-looking statements and other discussions of the risks, uncertainties and other challenges we face. These documents can be found via the investors page of our website, progressive.com. 
Shirley, we are now ready to take our first question.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Glasspiegel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Glasspiegel.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was very encouraged by the last quarterly policy expectancy lengthening that you highlighted in the 10-K. How excited are you by that trend? Do you think that this is a breakout that suggests that Snapshots measures you're taking are working?
componenttext: I was very encouraged by the last quarterly policy expectancy lengthening that you highlighted in the 10-K. How excited are you by that trend? Do you think that this is a breakout that suggests that Snapshots measures you're taking are working?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm excited about it. I've been waiting for it for a long time, so I'm actually very excited and I think the 5% thereabouts that we're seeing in the trailing 3 is really quite indicative for what we hope will flow through. Lots of reasons for that. Always
componenttext: I'm excited about it. I've been waiting for it for a long time, so I'm actually very excited and I think the 5% thereabouts that we're seeing in the trailing 3 is really quite indicative for what we hope will flow through. Lots of reasons for that. Always had to pin them down, but general excitement, absolutely, yes. If you take a look at some of our polished materials, you'll see that the average rate that consumers have seen over the last year regardless of channel, agency and direct is about 4%, which I would tell you to think more in those terms than specific rate changes. So 4% which means a good number of our consumers are still seeing rate changes that are on the high side of that. So as we mature into the rate revisions that we're now becoming even more comfortable with and rate levels that we're becoming more comfortable with, I would look forward to seeing, while continued positives, maybe not quite in the forward range, but a closer distribution or tighter distribution around the average. So we will potentially benefit even more so on retention without losing those higher end or the right-hand distribution around the average of 4 last year. So really nice movement, getting our new product into the marketplace, getting the rate level that we feel very comfortable with, maintaining that. You might remember we said at our IR meeting, we have a strong preference for 3 1% changes than 1 3% change, all of that really is a big part of how we're trying to make sure that retention is front and center and all of our thinking. So nice to see it coming through. Frankly, I'll tell you I'll be disappointed in that didn't continue.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Switching gears. The first quarter we've seen stressful investment environment. Are you maybe could update us on how the fixed income is performing, the stress lines? And are you thinking this in an opportunity to increase risk or are you de-risking
componenttext: Okay. Switching gears. The first quarter we've seen stressful investment environment. Are you maybe could update us on how the fixed income is performing, the stress lines? And are you thinking this in an opportunity to increase risk or are you de-risking on the portfolio?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Bill jump in there.
componenttext: I'll let Bill jump in there.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are taken taking as an opportunity to increase risk modestly. We've increased a bit in the corporate exposure, a little bit in the CMB as well. Some areas we've decreased risk and that would be primarily munis because those were traded really tig
componenttext: Sure. We are taken taking as an opportunity to increase risk modestly. We've increased a bit in the corporate exposure, a little bit in the CMB as well. Some areas we've decreased risk and that would be primarily munis because those were traded really tightly and very opposite for the rest of the fixed income markets. And also, we've reduced some of our high-yield exposure because the high-yield that we own has performed really, really well to the point where it's training at spreads similar to BBB papers. So for us, we're in a good position to take some risk and we're finding some more compelling opportunities to do that. Performance wise, we released our January numbers, which total return we'll release February, a couple of weeks.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Josh Sterling from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Josh Sterling from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd love to ask a question about the status of Snapshot. Over the past 6, you say you guys have announced you've been rolling out a new smartphone app and I think it's in the last annual meeting you walked us through, that you were iterating the pricing d
componenttext: I'd love to ask a question about the status of Snapshot. Over the past 6, you say you guys have announced you've been rolling out a new smartphone app and I think it's in the last annual meeting you walked us through, that you were iterating the pricing design to add discounts upfront. And I guess I was curious, just want a bit of an update on how many states you've rolled these things out with and as well as more importantly, what's then the consumer response? I guess, both from the app, which feels like a different customer interface and it's kind of a question of adoption and comfort and sort of more open ended questions about that, how consumers like the app and whether perhaps something will sell. And then separately, from a discount standpoint, what kind of lift did you see from this? Is there impact in conversion rates or maybe on new sales?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't done a little Snapshot for a while, I want to see if let me get all those points and give you some flavor of what's going on. Starting into this year, we're still seeing our policies initiated with a Snapshot influence discount, whatever it mig
componenttext:
We haven't done a little Snapshot for a while, I want to see if let me get all those points and give you some flavor of what's going on. Starting into this year, we're still seeing our policies initiated with a Snapshot influence discount, whatever it might be, to be faster than the rates of growth that you're seeing as we report on aggregate. So it's still our fastest-growing sector, that remains true for a long time, but certainly, even into January, that was true. Starting to get a feel for what's sort of mix of business is attainable. So I just gave you a quick look here, not to confuse you with any numbers but in our direct book of business, where we've been able to offer Snapshot and realistically, there's only 2 states now, California and North Carolina, where we're not offering it. But over a period of time, where the cohort or the Snapshot has been available, that cohort of business is now approximating about 40% of the direct business for places where it was available for some period of time. So think in terms of, can the little train really take momentum, we're looking to sort of 40% to 50% in the direct channel. Think I've told you before the acceptance in the direct channel far exceeds the agency channel and with the new changes we made, it was very clear that we were hoping to see agency uptake on the -- or the quotes include Snapshot with that discount being
[Audio Gap]
what I'd call overly dramatic movement, but significant on the small base. Actually, we have some good news to report there. We have actually introduced into 2 hot -- what I'll call higher average premium states: Florida, Louisiana. And we've seen the agent acceptance rates there or the agent penetration into new app, new coding, actually go up significantly. So probably approximating somewhere in the league of 1/2 to 2/3, the rate on our direct channels. So starting to make some correction there. And we're going to take a closer look, I think we did a better job of rolling that out through agents in those states. We'll take a closer look if what we did well there and make sure that we reinforce that in other places in the country. So net-net, pretty good sized penetration in our direct book and I don't want to project what the threshold might be as to overall penetration. But to think in terms of more than half the book is not unreasonable based on what we've experienced to date and now we're starting to see opportunities where the agency business perhaps is, yes, slower, but certainly starting to close some part of that gap. So good stuff there. 
With regard to the app, we've discussed that. I want to make it very clear that we've had apps that have approximated in one way, shape or form the activity -- for some time. That's not being an issue. The issue is really making sure we had an app that we felt had the data integrity that really match with the dongle and we got to the point where we actually have that application and very comfortable with it. And they're all sorts of stories that some of which are not as close to as others, but you need to be able to determine the difference between a train ride and a plane ride and the car ride. You need to know was the person got in the left door, the right door, are they driving, are they passenger. All those sorts of things are actually very important to us. So it's easy enough to create an app that does part of the job. It's very hard to create an app that does -- or gives us the level of integrity that we'd be comfortable swapping out for the information we get for the dongle. We think we're there. Unfortunately, it's probably going to take us a little over to get there in the marketplace than we might like. There's a fair amount of work to do on the IT side. But certainly in '16, we expect to see that roll out, but in maybe 4 or 5 isn't large numbers later in the year. 
I think we probably mentioned, we have a relationship with GM and Armstar that's been a little bit delayed, but we expect to be marketing that more actively in about the midyear time frame. So Snapshot, for lots of reasons, continues to be something very important to us, not only as an indicator of the source of everything that we think we'll do more of in the future, but it's really taking hold and you'll know the power of Snapshot relative to a rating variable. So ultimately, when we start to talk about penetration numbers that are really in the range of that 40%, perhaps even 50%, it makes different sometimes in segmentation. So we couldn't be more happy with what we see. I just don't know what the high watermark will be, but we're going to find out. And I hope it's really high.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could just touch briefly on your other big product development initiative rolling out to combined homeowners product channel, give us a sense of -- I think your live in at least a couple of states. It would be useful to have a little bit o
componenttext: I wonder if you could just touch briefly on your other big product development initiative rolling out to combined homeowners product channel, give us a sense of -- I think your live in at least a couple of states. It would be useful to have a little bit of color for how agents are responding, what kind of traction you're getting and then maybe if you're going to walk us through what your goals are for the program as you look out over the next year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And maybe I'll double team here with Trish here on a couple of points. Platinum is what we're talking about. And this is, in short, I don't want to repeat the things that were already written down, but in short, is a way that ASI property business a
componenttext: Sure. And maybe I'll double team here with Trish here on a couple of points. Platinum is what we're talking about. And this is, in short, I don't want to repeat the things that were already written down, but in short, is a way that ASI property business and Progressive come to the market looking as if they are simply 1. So let's not worry about the brand names, but the agents are seeing that as Platinum, we're in 12 states. We expect to be in an additional 22 this year. So that will give us some really nice penetration. Our goal is simple. Our goal is to be a valid and the most significant choice inside the agency channel for those customers who want to bundle their auto and home together. We're comfortable to face that either way, but we really like the bundles. ASI is seeing about 50% now of their new quote volume being bundled. So we really -- we're not getting the curtail in any way, shape or form monoline of either, but our real interest is in the bundle. We know what the effect of long-term retention there can be. So those things are great. Our interest is making sure on the agency channel, we offer a really viable option and a, as I put it, must-have solution for agents. We know we've got a great order of product. I don't think we need to dispute on that. We have ASI, we have a great homeowners product. We're going to work together to put that into a great package. And there's still work to be done. So we don't think we're across the finish line. We probably never got across the finish line. We can always make it better. And on the direct side, while ASI is not a bigger player on the direct side, that's obviously a future option that we have for going forward. Tricia, maybe you could talk a little bit about the sales force and how we're in the sales force to make sure that we get the message out as well as possible.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Josh, I think, too, what Glenn said before I say that we really, first of all, the second half of last year, getting the product out was really important to get that preferred business and that continues stable rate. And then we had to have both an agent
componenttext: Josh, I think, too, what Glenn said before I say that we really, first of all, the second half of last year, getting the product out was really important to get that preferred business and that continues stable rate. And then we had to have both an agent and a customer value proposition. So we know we need to add more commission for these preferred customers, match policy terms and then as we started to talk with our ASI partner, we realized we really needed to combine sales forces and have very specific sales reps that work with our Platinum agents. So we've just done that recently. We're very excited about that. And we continue to -- like we have 12 states out. We have continued to understand where we're competitive, we we're not, what we need to do, and I think agents understand that. We really want to make sure that we reward our agents not just with more commission, but with preference. So when they choose us as #1 or 2. In fact, just this week, John Sauerland and I were able to make some calls to agents that have reached some certain levels. We have hurdles to get over, determining how many bundles that you have in your agency. So while the data set with 12 states, I would consider 2016 really the year of execution, understanding more and more about, again, how to get that low pure premium business and on how to integrate the right sales force with these very specific agents.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Ian Gutterman with Balyasny.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Ian Gutterman with Balyasny.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, just a quick numbers question. When I was looking at your Snapshot surplus for the end of the year and your leverage normally have a close to 3x this year, you had about 2.7, which I'm assuming is the homeowners change obviously. Just when
componenttext: I guess, first, just a quick numbers question. When I was looking at your Snapshot surplus for the end of the year and your leverage normally have a close to 3x this year, you had about 2.7, which I'm assuming is the homeowners change obviously. Just when I backed that, I kind of took your normal auto lever, auto premiums, divided by the 2.9 to 3x and so for the rest, home was coming at about 1x levered, is that a good proxy?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: John jumping here. You're right, the 2.7 a little bit influenced by the home. We would probably go to run a home business at more like 1.5. And I expect over time, as these things, sometimes you get a little bit off, but I think in terms of we don't try t
componenttext: John jumping here. You're right, the 2.7 a little bit influenced by the home. We would probably go to run a home business at more like 1.5. And I expect over time, as these things, sometimes you get a little bit off, but I think in terms of we don't try to maximize on order of about 3 to 1 if we possibly can where we can, never works out perfectly and closer to our 1.5 on the homeowners business.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's what I was wondering. And then on the reserves, I guess, just first quickly, on the January average development, normally, I guess, I'm going back in time a little bit. There used to be fixed favorable for at least in January due to sort of a
componenttext: Okay. That's what I was wondering. And then on the reserves, I guess, just first quickly, on the January average development, normally, I guess, I'm going back in time a little bit. There used to be fixed favorable for at least in January due to sort of a catcher from the prior December. And I recall you changed that process about 3 or 4 years ago to smooth that out. And this January saw the lumpiness just in the other direction. It is still the same process or do we make a change in process back to the old way?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary here. I think the process change coming up the table, so let them take it away. But the unfavorable saw in December, I would -- I don't want to be cavalier about it, but I would tell you, don't be too concerned about that, that, that has been Februar
componenttext: Gary here. I think the process change coming up the table, so let them take it away. But the unfavorable saw in December, I would -- I don't want to be cavalier about it, but I would tell you, don't be too concerned about that, that, that has been February, a little bit January, then it wouldn't be prior year. It just happened that as the calendar closed and therefore you see prior year development come through, as we looked at our January development for '15 -- for '16, there was really nothing that was surprising over the prior year. So we're pretty comfortable with that. Gary, won't you put some more details on there.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary Traicoff, chief actuary. To your point, Rob, 3 to 4 years ago, we did make a process change and in the last few years, it looked stable. Wed happens is past January was really due to more late reported claims that happened in December, they g
componenttext: This is Gary Traicoff, chief actuary. To your point, Rob, 3 to 4 years ago, we did make a process change and in the last few years, it looked stable. Wed happens is past January was really due to more late reported claims that happened in December, they got reported in January. And if you think back to the end of December, we did have some storms come through, particularly out last week or so. So in January, we just recognized more late reported losses, which was really the driver of the development in January.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can clarify one other thing. I was looking in the K, on the reserves it said our net debt reserve balance assumes that's varied for your 2015 over 2014 will be 4.2% higher for personal auto and 9.2% higher for commercial auto. And I was trying to
componenttext: And if I can clarify one other thing. I was looking in the K, on the reserves it said our net debt reserve balance assumes that's varied for your 2015 over 2014 will be 4.2% higher for personal auto and 9.2% higher for commercial auto. And I was trying to contrast that earlier in the K, we talked about calendar year severity, when you give your frequency and severity stats, and the calendar year severity was, I guess, 3% per PD, 4% collision, minus 2 BI if I sort of weight those, I get a very low single-digit versus a 4.2 on the accident year. Is there a difference between that low single-digit and the 4.2 reserve releases? Or are you is there some other way to determine that?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question. Related to that, when I think of calendar period severity, which is the low numbers you were talking about. Our calendar period severity that came through in the year was fairly low, particularly in BI, it was actually negative. A
componenttext: That's a great question. Related to that, when I think of calendar period severity, which is the low numbers you were talking about. Our calendar period severity that came through in the year was fairly low, particularly in BI, it was actually negative. And that was really the driver of why our reserves developed so favorably in 2015. When we think ahead and going forward, we don't anticipate long-term severity will continue to be negative like that. So if we look at what we actually have booked in our reserving model amount we're anticipating roughly a 4% severity going forward on liability. Now that will include BI, PD, et cetera. So if you do all those cuts by state and by line, most of them are in the 2% to 6% range. But overall, it was about 4%. When I look at commercial lines, it is about 9%. Some of that is overly to mix changes in the business marketing targets we have. So if you normalize for that, think of it probably closer to a 6% range or so, which is actually fairly consistent with our commercial line severity in 2015.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you have something similar to the accident frequency in '15?
componenttext: And do you have something similar to the accident frequency in '15?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We did not report anything in their frequency. Typically, though, calendar year and accident year frequencies are fairly well in line. You're not going to have as much of a disconnect as you might have on the severity side, particularly with the BI in the
componenttext: We did not report anything in their frequency. Typically, though, calendar year and accident year frequencies are fairly well in line. You're not going to have as much of a disconnect as you might have on the severity side, particularly with the BI in the longtailed coverage.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Brian Meredith from UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Brian Meredith from UBS.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just back on the product,  a couple of quick questions here. First, how are PLEs looking so far with respect to the customers you're getting and then on that also just wondering, is there an opportunity here given the consolidation we've seen in the marke
componenttext: Just back on the product,  a couple of quick questions here. First, how are PLEs looking so far with respect to the customers you're getting and then on that also just wondering, is there an opportunity here given the consolidation we've seen in the market that we could potentially go after that right now?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Frank, you just give us a kind of the question again, the consolidation piece?
componenttext: Frank, you just give us a kind of the question again, the consolidation piece?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we've seen as far as consolidation and the high net worth market from homeowners perspective, is there an opportunity for you guys to really go out to that? I know agents are for new territories there.
componenttext: What we've seen as far as consolidation and the high net worth market from homeowners perspective, is there an opportunity for you guys to really go out to that? I know agents are for new territories there.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Let me take the first. I think we're showing you at some prior IR meetings and we're more than willing to show you, as we get more and more information, that the bundled customer really does give us that motion of a meaningful, I have to stress tha
componenttext: Great. Let me take the first. I think we're showing you at some prior IR meetings and we're more than willing to show you, as we get more and more information, that the bundled customer really does give us that motion of a meaningful, I have to stress that, a meaningful extension on our life expectancy. In my shareholders letter, I started to use some language that I think will become more common inside Progressive. Moving away from policy life expectancy to customer life expectancy. I think you get that, it's really we're looking to at least a piece of our business, and I stress that, we'll still always do the pieces that we do well. A piece of our business being customers that actually stay with us in a reasonably long period of time or actually not reasonably long, but very long period of time and have multiple products. So a way to think about that, yes, we are seeing -- yes, that was our hypothesis, yes, we're seeing it. And the data is solid and meaningful. I think quite frankly, we might even be understating the customer life expectancy yet because we haven't seen that kind of customer for a long period of time. Something just internally, and this is just to give you a little bit of a mindset how we think, we're starting to, and this is, I would say, something that 30 years ago, certainly was not was in our radar screen. How many -- what percentage of our customers are being with us for more than 10 years. And now we have a meaningful double-digit, let's say, around 15% of our customers that have been with us for more than 10 years. That wouldn't be a number that would impress USAA or State Farm, I'm sure. But relative to the repositioning of aggressive, that's a number that's very important and the type of customers that we're seeing to into that state decade and decade plus customers are the bundled customers. So nice stuff there. With regard to your question on the high net worth. I'm going to be very frank, we've got a big agenda in front of us. And we're going to probably play an something below the high net worth customer, just put it out on the table exactly that way. That doesn't mean that we won't make some phone calls and have other people's product to sell to those high net worth customers, at least in the home side, but that's probably not a focus that we can add to our property business anytime in the immediate future, given the very large market opportunity there is for us that we feel very comfortable in our realizing.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then any changes that we think about what with respect to their reinsurance program?
componenttext: And then any changes that we think about what with respect to their reinsurance program?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go through the reassurance. We know Trevor is actually here, but in the June, July timeframe, and John, correct if I'm wrong here. But no, I expect that we will take reinsurance with our property business very, very similar to the way that we have t
componenttext: We'll go through the reassurance. We know Trevor is actually here, but in the June, July timeframe, and John, correct if I'm wrong here. But no, I expect that we will take reinsurance with our property business very, very similar to the way that we have taken it in the past, at least for the excess layers. We may and likely will reassess some small part of a quota share that really isn't necessary from our perspective going forward. But in terms of the layers, we're not looking to take higher end risk any greater than we have taken in the past or ASI's taken in the past. And that was never the objective. The objective is to get more customers in the door. We'll take reasonable amount of risk, but we feel very good about the amount of risk we're taking and don't intend to extend that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] You're next question comes from Meyer Shields from KBW.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] You're next question comes from Meyer Shields from KBW.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a few cautions to understand your reporting and let me give 1 example. So you have indicator, direct renewal application changes that were 5% said, I think, for the year -- in earlier quarters 7% -- 7%, 8%. So should we look at that 5% as just a mo
componenttext: I have a few cautions to understand your reporting and let me give 1 example. So you have indicator, direct renewal application changes that were 5% said, I think, for the year -- in earlier quarters 7% -- 7%, 8%. So should we look at that 5% as just a modest dip from the 8%? Or is there a bigger bit in the fourth quarter to get the full year to 5%?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You want to take that?
componenttext: You want to take that?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I can take that. Recognize we do have a calendar year that in some years has more weeks than in others. So last December '14, you might recall, we had an extra week in the December release for you. So in that release, we also normalized the premium
componenttext: Sure. I can take that. Recognize we do have a calendar year that in some years has more weeks than in others. So last December '14, you might recall, we had an extra week in the December release for you. So in that release, we also normalized the premium for the month for you to about a perspective there. So I would not interpret that at all to be a dip in renewals, the PLE is what you should be looking at to understand trends in terms of customer retention. And as we discussed earlier, we're seeing good changes there. So I think you're just seeing a recording anomaly, nothing material.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now. That helps a lot. Thanks for clarifying. And in Second Life look at the property side, so if I'm doing the math right, you acquired $220 million of reserves and released a little bit more than $30 million, is that sort of 15% a good representation of
componenttext: Now. That helps a lot. Thanks for clarifying. And in Second Life look at the property side, so if I'm doing the math right, you acquired $220 million of reserves and released a little bit more than $30 million, is that sort of 15% a good representation of ASI's reserving philosophy?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I'm going to sit down into that a little bit more generically. One of the things that I am delighted about in the first 9 months of being together is that we feel, and I think ASI feels, that we have some skills to offer and clearly they have product
componenttext: No. I'm going to sit down into that a little bit more generically. One of the things that I am delighted about in the first 9 months of being together is that we feel, and I think ASI feels, that we have some skills to offer and clearly they have product and skills to offer as well. But one of the places that we were able to actually take in together is on the reserving inside and we now have an actuary that has been on our staff, working directly for Trevor, CFO of ASI, but also having very direct line or whatever you want to call it. As a integral part of our reserving group and during the course of that 9 months, we applied some different techniques, we looked at data a little bit more specifically to ASI versus industry data that have been done before, there was no right or wrong, we're digging in, in a way that perhaps there's a little bit more intense, a little more reflective of the way Progressive has done reserving. In this particular taste, it turned out they had some releases. Could have been that are, we would have adjusted that either way. But I would tell you that the reflection of the releases this time is a little bit more from a highly intense review, overlaying some models, overlaying some techniques, looking at data, looking at it more frequently and what I expect going forward, obviously, I cannot guarantee anything. But what I expect going forward is we'll be much more on a glide path of a kind of approaches that we take traditionally with our order of business and I suspect the volatility will reduce. So probably one-time volatility that is reflective of that process, but frankly, it's a great opportunity for us to really work together and taking a look. I have to say is release, not an ad, but frankly, I feel much better that we've had the deep study and everybody is very comfortable.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Jay Gelb with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Jay Gelb with Barclays.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that you've gone through the year end 2015 process, I just want to get your updated views on why you feel Progressive is not being impacted nearly as much on the personal auto side as a result of increased miles driven, translating into worse claims f
componenttext: Now that you've gone through the year end 2015 process, I just want to get your updated views on why you feel Progressive is not being impacted nearly as much on the personal auto side as a result of increased miles driven, translating into worse claims frequency trends like we're seeing for essentially the rest of the industry.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jay, I might challenge the rest of the industry a little bit, well, notwithstanding the frequency was up, we're porting sort of across the board 2, 2.5. I don't think those are medically different than the PCI reporting part of the industry. For we know t
componenttext:
Jay, I might challenge the rest of the industry a little bit, well, notwithstanding the frequency was up, we're porting sort of across the board 2, 2.5. I don't think those are medically different than the PCI reporting part of the industry. For we know that there were a couple of very large and very notable competitors who know perfectly well how to calculate frequency. They reported high numbers. And that's just a fact. I can't necessarily know other than at least in 1 case, probably a mixed adjustment that would really we needed to be made to sort of normalize those numbers. But I'm not sure that we're the anomaly on that relative to the industry. And with regard to -- but to be fair, anytime and I mean this sincerely, anytime we see anybody else seeing something that we're not seeing, trust me, the radar just goes off like crazy and we make sure that we're not the ones waiting too long to see that kind of effect. But as it's played through from order perspective, we really didn't see a great deal in frequency, we didn't see any major trends, we sort of a little bit in the third quarter, but for the most part, that 2, 2.5, not bad. Now remember, systemically, long term, we think maybe frequency is headed for reduction, just for a loss of reasons with vehicle technology. 
Miles driven, no question that would be the usual suspect for increase in frequency and to the extent we didn't see it as much as some others, I'll also tell you that our most recent reporting on mileage increases related clearly to gas prices was starting to see the second half of '15, we did see the second half of '15 be a lot less dramatic of an increase over the prior year than the first half of '15. And our most recent data points might suggest that we have hit sort of the threshold of miles to be driven. I think we'd be better off waiting for the spring and summer to see if we get another spring and summer effect, but for the most part, the more recent data points we're seeing up to and including January, since we get there in real time data, is that '16 mileage is not dramatic or not even different than '15 mileage. And we've seen that even in the last data points of '15 over '14. So the incremental, yes, there was income of the first half of '15 that was very measurable, quite notable, 3% to 5% on a month to month basis. But we're starting to see that level out. We still see in the mix of miles driven, little shift about a 1% shift still to trips over FT miles, we're not seeing dramatic and seasonal adjusted breaking rates are probably not a statistic was other companies talk about. But something that we're particularly interested in. So net-net, the gas price change may have played its way through. I'm going to say that with some ability to retract my statement next time we talk in May or whatever. So stay tuned. But I would just correct that maybe the rest of the industry didn't see the frequency quite as high as perhaps in Allstate and I think of the 2 that come to mind when we see that. And certainly, the 2 that took me though is more reflective of that.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Glenn, all the miles driven trends that you're talking about, that's based on Progressive's own data?
componenttext: Glenn, all the miles driven trends that you're talking about, that's based on Progressive's own data?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We use Snapshot population to see if we can get what kind of about this. We have been look at sort of daily, weekly, whatever frequency we can because these are the sorts of things that for years, we have reported even to you, we don't always know ad
componenttext: Yes. We use Snapshot population to see if we can get what kind of about this. We have been look at sort of daily, weekly, whatever frequency we can because these are the sorts of things that for years, we have reported even to you, we don't always know address frequency. You don't always know what drives severity, now we actually do have at least 1 proxy for frequency and miles driven is something we can measure. So it's only a piece of the puzzle. But we're pretty obsessed with trying to get it.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I could imagine that. The only other thing I want to touch base on with regard to what some a large -- larger than the industry in personal auto are seeing with regards to the deteriorating margins. So if the frequency impacts the Progressive seeing is no
componenttext: I could imagine that. The only other thing I want to touch base on with regard to what some a large -- larger than the industry in personal auto are seeing with regards to the deteriorating margins. So if the frequency impacts the Progressive seeing is not inconsistent with that of the industry, when you feel the Progressive is personal auto margins haven't been really impacted at all?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's probably a longer story. But let me suggest to you that -- and we've done this and many, many calls. I've always said, when we see situations that make us believe that rates will go up, we tend to take an early. It wasn't that many years ago
componenttext: Well, that's probably a longer story. But let me suggest to you that -- and we've done this and many, many calls. I've always said, when we see situations that make us believe that rates will go up, we tend to take an early. It wasn't that many years ago that we took and talking in aggregate, it's not always the best thing, but it might work for this. We took rates up and frankly, some of the trends didn't materialize to the degree that we thought. Our penalty there is we actually go a little slower with healthy margins. However, at more recent times, we got into a rate level that we thought was appropriate and perhaps, others weren't quite at that level and therefore, needed to take their rates up more. So the starting point matters. And that was sort of my point before and I like the thing that we're trying to ride the request of the breaking wave. We want to stay on the crest all the time. When you fall over the crest and your margins starts to deteriorate, typically that's associated with a big rate. And we all know the implications of that, to retention, to MPS and to growth. The trick for us is really staying on that crest. And as I had mentioned earlier, as opposed to looking at rate take by rate filings, which you could look premium weighted adjusted basis, you'll see that the industry is about just 2.5 to 3.5 last year, some exceptions to that for sure on the highside and low side. But I would always draw your attention to sort of what's their realized average premium? And you see in our case that was about 4% in both channels. And we have ways that are not going to get into in great detail but of making sure that we built in some trends into our rating factors as well. So that doesn't always come through in the published rate changes. So our objective is really to stay on that crest of the wave and answering your question, it depends on the starting point. So we were not in adequate and didn't need to take a big rate increase in we actually had been taking small bites of the apple, and really keep taking bites of the apple, my expectation is in the first quarter this year, we'll take about probably the better part of 1 point at this in our direct channel and maybe close to that in our agency channel. So we've always take that kind of a rate. I'm not going to speculate for the whole year, but it might be sort of slightly below the 4% and ask the question before about severities. And while we did have the -- for 2 of the situation, those severities going down and therefore, we can release reserves based on the negative severity trends we saw. I will tell you one of the first lessons I've ever learned in this business was people don't get less expensive to fix. So we certainly don't plan negative trends into our pricing indications and we're much more likely to reflect the kinds of numbers that Gary talked about going forward. So long way of saying, but our job is to say on the crest of the wave, and the good news is that we are not currently in the position of taking a significant hammer to our rates, we haven't had to for some time. And if we can stay in that crest of the wave without falling over by taking small bites of the apple, that's our objective. And that produces a very nice outcomes.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016

And it looks like there are no further questions. So Shirley, I will turn it back over to you for the closing script.

componenttext:
Welcome to the Progressive Corporation's Investor Relations Conference Call. This conference is also available via the audio webcast. [Operator Instructions] In addition, this conference is being recorded at the request of Progressive. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. 
The company will not make detailed comments in addition to those provided in its annual reports on Form 10-K and our report to shareholders and the letter to shareholders, which has been posted on the company's website and we'll use this conference call to respond to questions. 
Acting as moderator for the call will be Julia Hornack. At this time, I'll turn the call over to Ms. Hornack.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; Tricia Griffith, our Personal Lines Chief Financial Officer; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call i
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to Progressive's conference call. Participating on today's call are Glenn Renwick, our CEO; John Sauerland, our CFO; Tricia Griffith, our Personal Lines Chief Financial Officer; and Bill Cody, our Chief Investment Officer. The call is scheduled to last about an hour. 
As always, our discussions on this call may include forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations and are subject to the many risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events and results to differ materially from those discussed during this call. Additional information concerning those risks and uncertainties is available in our 2015 annual report on Form 10-K, where you will find discussions of the risk factors affecting our businesses, safe harbor statements related to forward-looking statements and other discussions of the risks, uncertainties and other challenges we face. These documents can be found via the investors page of our website, progressive.com. 
Shirley, we are now ready to take our first question.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Glasspiegel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Bob Glasspiegel.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was very encouraged by the last quarterly policy expectancy lengthening that you highlighted in the 10-K. How excited are you by that trend? Do you think that this is a breakout that suggests that Snapshots and some other measures you've taken are worki
componenttext: I was very encouraged by the last quarterly policy expectancy lengthening that you highlighted in the 10-K. How excited are you by that trend? Do you think that this is a breakout that suggests that Snapshots and some other measures you've taken are working?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm excited about it. I've been waiting for it for a long time, so I'm actually pretty excited and I think the 5% thereabouts that we're seeing in the trailing 3 is really quite indicative for what we hope will flow through. Lots of reasons for that. Alwa
componenttext: I'm excited about it. I've been waiting for it for a long time, so I'm actually pretty excited and I think the 5% thereabouts that we're seeing in the trailing 3 is really quite indicative for what we hope will flow through. Lots of reasons for that. Always had to pin them down, but general excitement, absolutely, yes. If you take a look at some of our polished materials, you'll see that the average rate that consumers have seen over the last year regardless of channel, agency and direct is about 4%, which I would tell you to think more in those terms than specific rate changes. So 4% which means a good number of our consumers are still seeing rate changes that are on the high side of that. So as we mature into the rate revisions that we're now becoming even more comfortable with and rate levels that we're becoming more comfortable with, I would look forward to seeing, while continued positives, maybe not quite in the 4 range, but a closer distribution or tighter distribution around the average. So we will potentially benefit even more so on retention without losing those higher end or the right-hand distribution around the average of 4 last year. So really nice movement, getting our new product into the marketplace, getting a rate level that we feel very comfortable with, maintaining that. You might remember we said at our IR meeting, we have a strong preference for 3 1% changes than 1 3% change. All of that really is a big part of how we're trying to make sure that retention is front and center in all of our thinking. So nice to see it coming through. Frankly, I would tell you I'll be disappointed if that didn't continue.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Switching gears. The first quarter we've seen sort of a stressful investment environment. Are you -- maybe could update us on how the fixed income is performing, the stress lines? And are you taking this as an opportunity to increase risk or are you
componenttext: Okay. Switching gears. The first quarter we've seen sort of a stressful investment environment. Are you -- maybe could update us on how the fixed income is performing, the stress lines? And are you taking this as an opportunity to increase risk or are you de-risking on the portfolio?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Bill jump in there.
componenttext: I'll let Bill jump in there.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We are taken taking this as an opportunity to increase risk modestly. We've increased a bit in the corporate exposure, a little bit in the CMBS as well. Some areas we've decreased risk, I mean, that would be primarily munis because those have traded
componenttext: Sure. We are taken taking this as an opportunity to increase risk modestly. We've increased a bit in the corporate exposure, a little bit in the CMBS as well. Some areas we've decreased risk, I mean, that would be primarily munis because those have traded really tightly and very opposite to the rest of the fixed income markets. And also, we've reduced some of our high-yield exposure because the high yield that we own has performed really, really well to the point, where it's trading at spreads similar to BBB papers. So for us, we're in a good position to take some risk, and we're finding some more compelling opportunities to do that. Performance wise, we released our January numbers, which I mean, our total return we'll release February, in a couple of weeks.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Josh Stirling with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I love to ask a question about the status of Snapshot. Over the past 6 months or so you guys have announced you've been rolling out a new smartphone app and I think at the last annual meeting you walked us through, that you were iterating the pricing desi
componenttext: I love to ask a question about the status of Snapshot. Over the past 6 months or so you guys have announced you've been rolling out a new smartphone app and I think at the last annual meeting you walked us through, that you were iterating the pricing design to add discounts upfront. And I guess, I was curious, just want a bit of an update on how many states you've rolled these things out with? And as well as more importantly, what's then the consumer response? I guess, both from the app, which feels like a different customer interface and it's kind of the question of adoption and comfort and sort of more open-ended questions about that, how consumers like the app and whether perhaps something will sell. And then separately, from a discounts, what kind of lift are you seeing from this? Is there an impact in conversion rates or maybe on new sales?

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we haven't done a little Snapshot update for a while, so let me see if I can get all of those points and give you some flavor of what's going on. Starting into this year, we're still seeing our policies initiated with a Snapshot influence disco
componenttext:
Yes. Well, we haven't done a little Snapshot update for a while, so let me see if I can get all of those points and give you some flavor of what's going on. Starting into this year, we're still seeing our policies initiated with a Snapshot influence discount, whatever it might be, to be faster than the rates of growth that you're seeing as we report on aggregate. So it's still our fastest-growing sector, that remains true for a long time, but certainly, even into January, that was true. Starting to get a feel for what sort of mix of business is attainable. So I'll just gave you a quick look here, not to confuse you with any numbers but in our direct book of business, where we've been able to offer Snapshot and realistically, there's only 2 states now, California, North Carolina, where we're not offering it. But over a period of time, where the cohort or the Snapshot has been available, that cohort of business is now approximating about 40% of the direct business for places where it was available for some period of time. So think in terms of, can the little train really take momentum, we're looking to sort of 40% to 50% in the direct channel. I think I've told you before the acceptance in the direct channel far exceeds the agency channel and with the new change that we made, it was very clear that we were hoping to see agency uptake on the -- or the quotes include Snapshot with that discount being what I'd call overly dramatic movement, but significant on the small base. Actually, we have some good news to report there. We have actually introduced it into 2 hot, what I'll call higher average premium states: Florida, Louisiana. And we've seen the agent acceptance rates there or the agent penetration into new app, new coding, actually go up significantly, so probably approximating somewhere in the league of 1/2 to 2/3, the rate on our direct channels. So starting to make some traction there. And we're going to take a closer look, I think we did a better job of rolling that out to agents in those states, who'll take a closer look at what we did well there and make sure that we reinforce that in other places in the country. So net-net, pretty good-sized penetration in our direct book and I don't want to project what the threshold might be as to overall penetration. But to think in terms of more than half the book is not unreasonable based on what we've experienced to date and now we're starting to see opportunities, where the agency business perhaps is, yes, slower, but certainly starting to close some part of the gap. So good stuff there. With regard to the app, we've discussed that. I want to make it very clear that we've had apps that have approximated in one way, shape or form the activity that -- for some time that's not being an issue. The issue is really making sure we had an app that we felt had the data or integrity that really matched with the in-car dongle, and we have got to the point where we actually have that application and very comfortable with it. And they're all sorts of stories that some of which I'm not as close to as others, but you need to be able to determine the difference between a train ride and a plane ride and a car ride. You need to know was the person got in the left door, the right door, are they driving, are they passenger. All those sorts of things are actually very important to us. So it's easy enough to create an app that does part of the job. It's very hard to create an app that does the -- or gives us the level of integrity that we'd be comfortable swapping out for the information we get for the dongle. We think we're there. Unfortunately, it's probably going to take us a little longer to get that into marketplace than we might like. There's a fair amount of work to do on the IT side. But certainly in '16, we expect to see that rollout, but it maybe for all intents and purposes in large numbers, later in the year. 
I think we have probably mentioned, we have a relationship with GM and OnStar that's been a little bit delayed, but we expect to be marketing that more actively in about the midyear time frame. So Snapshot, for lots of reasons, continues to be something very important to us, not only as an indicator of the sorts of things that we think we'll do more of in the future, but it's really taking hold and you'll know the power of Snapshot relative to a rating variable. So ultimately, when we start talking about penetration numbers that are really in the range of that 40%, perhaps even 50%, it certainly make a difference in terms of segmentation. So we couldn't be more happy with what we see. I just don't know what the high watermark will be, but we're going to find out. And I hope it's really high.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. I wonder if you could just touch briefly on your other big product development initiative rolling out the combined homeowners product needs through channel, give us a sense of -- I think your live at least in a couple of states. It
componenttext: That's really helpful. I wonder if you could just touch briefly on your other big product development initiative rolling out the combined homeowners product needs through channel, give us a sense of -- I think your live at least in a couple of states. It would be useful to have a little bit of color for how agents are responding, what kind of traction you're getting and then maybe if you'd be going to walk us through what your goals are for the program as you look out over the next year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe I'll double team here with Tricia here on a couple of points. Platinum is what we're talking about. And this is, in short, I don't want to repeat the things that were already written down, but in short, is the way that ASI property business an
componenttext: Sure. Maybe I'll double team here with Tricia here on a couple of points. Platinum is what we're talking about. And this is, in short, I don't want to repeat the things that were already written down, but in short, is the way that ASI property business and Progressive come to the market looking as if they are simply one. So let's not worry about the brand names, but the agents are seeing that as Platinum, we're in 12 states. We expect to be in an additional 22 this year. So that will give us some really nice penetration. Our goal is simple. Our goal is to be a valid and most significant choice inside the agency channel for those customers, who want to bundle their auto and home together. We're comfortable to face that either way, but we really like the bundles. ASI is seeing about 50% now of their new quote volume being bundled. So we really -- we're not going to curtail in any way, shape or form monoline of either, but our real interest is in the bundle. We know what the effect of long-term retention there can be. So those things are great. Our interest is making sure on the agency channel, we offer a really viable option and a, as I put it, must-have solution for agents. We know we've got a great order of product. I don't think there's any dispute on that. We have ASI, we have a great homeowners product. We're going to work together to put that into a great package, and there's still work to be done. So we don't think we're across the finish line. We probably never will get across the finish line. We can always make it better. And on the direct side, while ASI is not a bigger player on the direct side, that's obviously a future option that we have for going forward. Tricia, maybe you could talk a little bit about the sales force and how we are into the sales force to make sure that we get the message out as well as possible.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Josh, I think, too, what Glenn said before I say that we really, first of all, the second half of last year, getting the product out, the AT product was really important to get that preferred business and then continue with stable rates. And then we
componenttext: Yes. Josh, I think, too, what Glenn said before I say that we really, first of all, the second half of last year, getting the product out, the AT product was really important to get that preferred business and then continue with stable rates. And then we had to have both an agent and a customer value proposition. So we know, we needed to add more commission for these preferred customers, match policy terms and then as we started to talk with our ASI partners, we realized, we really needed to combine sales forces and have very specific sales reps that work with our Platinum agents. So we've just done that recently. We're very excited about that. And we continue to -- like we have 12 states out. We have continued to understand where we're competitive, where we're not. What we need to do. And I think agents understand that. We really want to make sure that we reward our agents not just with more commission, but with preference. So when they choose us as #1 or #2. In fact, just this week, John Sauerland and I are able to make some calls to agents that have reached some certain levels. We have hurdles to get over, on determining how many bundles that you have in your agency. So while the data set with 12 states, I would consider 2016 really the year of execution, understanding more and more about, again, how to get that low pure premium business and on how to integrate the right sales force with these very specific agents.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016

componenttext: John, jump in here. You're right, the 2.7 a little bit influenced by the home. We would probably prefer to run the home business at more like 1.5. And I expect over time, as these things, sometimes you get a little bit off, but think in terms of we don't try to maximize on order at about 3:1 if we possibly can where we can, never works out perfectly and closer to our 1.5 on the homeowners business.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's why I was wondering. Okay, great.
