headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you for those out of counter who came in and welcome to Progressive's 2016 Investor Relations Day. We're glad to have you. I think you're all familiar with the Safe Harbor statement and if not, there's also a copy in your
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you for those out of counter who came in and welcome to Progressive's 2016 Investor Relations Day. We're glad to have you. I think you're all familiar with the Safe Harbor statement and if not, there's also a copy in your materials as the reference guide.
So this particular Investor Relations meeting represents a really big change. For many, many years, Glenn Renwick used to host this meeting, in fact, I think he started them. Last week, Glenn celebrated his 30th anniversary with Progressive, of which more than half of that he was our CEO and President. During his tenure as CEO, he tripled the company in size. So by most record books you would say, that is phenomenal and it is. But it's not just that. It's not just what Glenn did, it's how he did it. Always making sure to instill in us that desire to win but doing it in the right way, always following our core values. He always would set the bar higher every year for all of us. And then, he won't walk away, he will help us get over and that is really his legacy. So Glenn, on behalf of the 30,000 Progressive people, our shareholders and the customers we're privileged to serve, thank you for well being Progressive.
Okay, enough about Glenn. I thought what I do to start off is just remind you of our segments. So we outlined these several years ago when we first started talking about our destination area strategy. So I'll just swiftly go over those. The focus today will be on the Robinsons and we're really excited to talk to you about what we have done since he last met you in May of 2015.
So, Sam. Sam is the segment we grow up with, that we call him inconsistently insured. He is who Progressive -- he put us on the map, and we call him non-standard. He cares about rates, doesn't stay very long but he could come back. We love Sam. We want to write all the Sam's we can possibly write as long as it reaches our profitability goal.
Diane. Diane is a big part of the Destination Era. We talked in the past about her being a future Robertson. Diane is an auto customer and she rents. So she may have renters insurance with us and what we hope is that as her needs evolve and she buys a home, gets married, that we evolve with her. It's the notion of Diane graduating to be a Robinson. She's our largest customer base so the opportunity there is immense.
The Wrights. The Wrights are unbundled auto and home so they have Progressive home and someone else's auto. Again, we love The Wrights. We see them as future Robinsons because we hope that if they decide to shop their homeowners, they come with us and become a Robinson.
The Robinsons. That's what we today is all about and most of destination area is all about. The auto home bundle. The Robinsons are 40% of the market so the opportunity here is really great and we are really proud of how the momentum we've had in the last 18 months in particular in obtaining Robinsons.
Before we get started, what I thought I do as the new CEO is step back and just take stock of some objectives and some fundamentals that will stay the same during my tenure of things that might evolve. And clearly, with Glenn's leadership, I was a part of the team that developed the strategy around the Destination Era. So to make a turn and do something differently would make sense. I believe in this model, the execution has been great and I'm excited about our future. But things do evolve as a team as we know more.
When we start with our first and most important objective, profit. We want to make at least $0.04 of underwriting profit of every $1 of premium. 96 is essential to our culture. You're actually, sitting in there's called Studio 96 so you know how integrated it is into everything we do. It continues to be our most important objective and that won't change. There is, however, an added dimension with the auto home bundle. We're looking at how 2 independent margins can be optimized for that package. So while the 96 will stay the same, how it will be derived will absolutely evolve.
Growth. We want to grow as fast as we can with 2 constraints: One, the profit objective I just outlined; and two, our ability to service our customers. That second one is really important to us. So about 18 months ago, we had a -- 3 model on the streets, it was working, we were getting a lot more preferred customers, we also saw the opportunity when some of our competition pulled back to spend more on advertising, specifically, in the digital option. So we knew at that point we had a lot of opportunities to grow. We made a decision at that time to hire well in advance of need, so from the claims organization as well as our customer relationship management organization, both on the audit side and on the commercial side. And I'm so pleased that we did that because we did get that growth. We got that preferred growth. And in addition, we have things that happened that wouldn't necessarily planned for in the form of catastrophes. So we've been able to service our customers no matter if it's a cap or a regular just increase in losses based on growth.
It is sort of a rule here Progressive that whether on the claims side of the product side, if you think people were growing too fast, you're absolutely have to raise your hand and say, no more growth, we can't do this and we have done that in the past. I'm so delighted to say that this year, we didn't have to do that because we prepared and hired in advance of need. So when I think about growth and profit and that balance, year-to-date with audit being the most recent time frame with a 96.15% [indiscernible] net room premium growth. If we ended the year today, it's just a phenomenal year especially with the business that we've been putting on the growth. I'm extraordinarily happy. If we were the same margin at 96.2% and had 4% growth with the same set of circumstances, I wouldn't be as happy. If we were at 88% with 0% growth, I wouldn't be as happy. I'm very, very pleased with our growth. It's really sort of a perfect storm. So we have this new business and we talked and talked at the conference calls about the sort of new business hacks that you have won a combined wrench was higher in that first term and we had that coming at us and then, we had cat. This year, we have on our CR, 3 points of our combined ratio are in the form of cats, which is compared to this time last year, about a 1.5%. In fact, last month with Louisiana storm, it was over 4 points of our CR. So you can't plan for cat, I believe, I'm watching Matthew McConnaughy. You can't plan for, you can't plan for how you react to those cats. I am extraordinarily pleased with how we have reacted specifically the Louisiana storm. So about 3-weeks ago, a group of us flew down and spent some time in and Baton Rouge, Louisiana to make sure our employees were okay, our customers were okay, and I was just amazed. I was amazed that our cat team who went down there and just made sure they took it upon themselves to their customers back in their feet. We literally had employees who were laying in bed and they found out their home was flooded when they put their foot in water, yet they came to work that day to help our customers. In fact, as of yesterday, we have closed 96% of those flood claims, which is really amazing because they're complex claims, mostly total losses. So again, I'm so amazed that what we're able to do and what we're able to do. And what we are ready with whatever happens with Matthew, as of today, we have a plan and we'll figure it out. That's what we do.
So for me, again, just to wrap up in that part, profit growth, very happy, very proud especially with how we've been increasing our preferred business the Robinsons and we're going to talk a lot about that today.
I thought I'd take you to just a stab at some of the financial fundamentals. So it won't change. I think they work with our business plan. We want to continue to balance operating risk with the risk of investing in financing activities in order to have sufficient capital to support our growth. So that's the overview. On the operating side, we want to maintain pricing and reserving discipline. So when we talked about our pricing, we talked about managing targets. We talked about targets as the lowest definition, so whether it's on agency direct side, product state, we really segment our targets and that's another reason why I'm so positive about this new business because we look at the new business coming in and say, is it out of our targets? Great, that's going to run off profitably. So we're excited about that.
We want to have a premium to surplus at a below state of minimum requirement. So on auto, that's a 3:1 and about half of that for home. And on the loss reserving side, we want to make sure loss reserves are adequate and developed with a minimal variant. Year-to-date, very proud of that. We are pretty close but are limited on the favorable side, which is the side you want to be in. On investing side, we want to maintain a liquid diversified and high-quality portfolio. We managed our investments on a total return basis which are very consistent with how we report our comprehensive income. And on the risk side, we want to manage interest rate, credit, prepayment, concentration and extension risks. Lastly, on the financing side, we want to maintain sufficient capital to support the insurance operations. That's measured by maintaining a debt below 30% of total capital value. So we're just slightly over 20% right now and that's after issuing $500 million worth of debt in August. We want to neutralize dilution from equity-based compensation in the year of issuance and we do that by repurchasing shares. And finally, we were investing capital and expanding the business when it meets our objectives. A perfect example of this is our acquisition of ARX. We didn't necessarily feel like we had to have a homeowners or homeowners company. What we felt this would have to have access to that addressable market. That is a $300 billion market with auto and home. We needed to have access and it just so happened that we've been working with the company that we've had a high amount of respect for that had a very similar culture and so is a perfect relationship the start. So we're very pleased with the use of capital in acquiring ARX. Any use of under leveraged capital, we will buy back shares or issue dividends whether special or variable.
So let's get to the 96 since we are slightly over at this point, I want to walk you through how we look at it. This is just a basic refresher. So everybody gets to a 96, all of our customers it simply gets there but sometimes in vastly different ways. On the direct side, you can see we run a much higher combined ratio in that first arm. That's based on the fact that we have a little higher lost costs and some underwriting costs but most of all, we frontload all of our acquisitions cost in the direct side in that first term.
On the Asian side, we have a little bit more losses, a little bit more underwriting, but it's a relatively fixed commission expense, so much lower in the first term. I want to take you through the direct side, 2 ends of the spectrum. You have Sam and the Robinsons. Even to the same dynamic, they both blended a loss of the first term. But what is not evident is on a monthly reporting or even a quarterly reporting is the fact that this very high retaining business, the Robinsons, can stay 3 times, actually, more than 3 times longer than the Sam, are expanding our invisible balance sheet. So bringing on more of those Robinsons really build the intrinsic value of Progressive's.
So here's a basic income statement and it's directly accurate. So if you look at again, Sam and Robinsons, you look at revenue. Clearly the Robinsons are higher based on the fact that they stay longer and they have higher average written premium. If you look at the operating expenses, which of course are losses, LAEs, expense ratio, you quickly notice that neither of these equal to 96, those numbers represent a nominal value of the cash flow. So they're under 96. Our lifetime target, 96 combined ratio, for our direct business, we discount the cash flows to recover our acquisition expenses. So that will be different in different segments depending on how long they stay. The difference between those of course is our underwriting income. And then there's other income that we have, both on the investment side for both Sam and Robinsons and the commissions side for just the Robinsons. So whether it's affiliated partner like ASI or other homeowners curious, we get commissions when we have those bundles. So as you can see, the value of the Robinson, a pretax value is over 4 times that of a Sam. Again, we love Sam as long as we can make money on them but the value of a Robinson is extraordinary and the fact that we have grown Robinson substantially the last 18 months, really does grow the value, the intrinsic value of Progressive.
So for years, we have shared with you the invisible balance sheet. We talked last year about unearned lifetime and premium. So when we think about business coming on board, we look at new apps, for example. So in this year for ricin Robinson, we've grown you apps 30% and 40% respectively. That's pretty great. We look at average written premium. Our average premium has come up across all segments. and then, we look at PLE. This connectivity to be a spoiler alert for Andrew section 5 finally made a breakthrough attention purely. So both of those 3 things are really exciting. So we thought, we'd share with you one other metric that we look at internally that we call ULEP, under the lifetime underwriting process. So you'll see that the colors represent a segment so green for the Robinsons, pink for the Wrights, et cetera. On the Y axis, you see ULEP in million and on the X axis, you'll see the timeframe of which we're looking out. So why don't we start to grow right around that much of last year to our most recent data point. As you can see, the majority of our segments are growing substantially in ULEP, which again, is building that intrinsic value. In fact, the Robinsons are growing over 60%.
The chart underneath showed all of the segments year-over-year growth in ULEP and again, all are growing, so you can see the Robinsons are growing at a really quick clip. That's exciting for us.
I'm going to shift gears now and talk about how important understanding the Destination Era is to the 30,000 Progressive people that work on getting our customers indoor and making sure we nurture them along the way. We look at it in terms of our different frameworks. This is a framework for you, it's called our strategic pillars. So let me talk about the first one, our culture. Our culture is so important and it's not something you can really adequately describe unless you spent time on a Progressive, it's not something you're going to see on a spreadsheet but it is really special and it's really different and we know it's a competitive advantage. It's really at the root of how it started and that is doing the right thing and we want to win but you always want to do the right thing and it's really rooted in our core values. I am privileged to speak at every new hire class, actually, with that, with 1 Monday with a couple hundred new claims reps and my sole topic is our core value. I talked about 15 or 20 minutes, used some examples and then, let them ask questions. It's so important to me for them on their first day or the first week for their second week to know what an important part that is a Progressive, our value.
Earlier this year, many of us were in us to celebrate a milestone in Progressive, $20 billion in earned premiums and we've got face-to-face with over half of our employees, over 50,000 people just to celebrate and say thank you for all that you do and then of course talk about the next milestone and the next milestone and it was really rewarding and that again is a big part of our culture.
Our brand. We want to be the brand people want. So whether it's awareness or preference or consideration, those things are important but what we really want is to be able to, when people buy an insurance product from Progressive, that they feel confident that they've made the right position and they continue to feel confident as we service them and as we add more and more policies. Want to spend money on consumer marketing and customer marketing. We've talked often about how we wanted our customer marketing be as savvy as our consumer marketing. Andrew Quigg is going to talk a little bit about that today but we continue to resource that as an important part of nurturing our customers.
Competitive prices. In a business with all margins, this is very important to us. As we all around segmentation. You're going to hear a lot about that today, so John Sauerland is going to talk about our continued evolution with UBI and our segmentation and how important that variable is. Pat Callahan is going to talk about segmentation and the product model that we continue to elevate as well as our bundled competitiveness. Andrew Quigg will talk about segmentation of the customer part and using data to get out in front of our customers to know what they need when they need them. So this is really important part of our -- really central to things that we do is segmentation. We continue to hone in on that.
Another part of competent prices is really having a loss structure. So the claim side, we continued to have that near-perfect balance of cost and quality, so pushing down LAE while pushing up the accuracy and doing a fantastic job. On the expense side, we look at what we call non-acquisition expense ratio, so we continue to try to push that down, be more efficient and then, give that pricing advantage to our customers in the form of competitive prices.
And the last pillar is meeting the broader needs of our customers. What products do they want? When do they wanted, how do they want to shop? We want to measure we can have personalized service and products for each of our customers. So if you want to buy through an agent, yet service online or through a chat, we want to make sure if it fits your needs, we are there for you. We want to pick up the phone and say, yes, we can do that absolutely or whether or not we do that through our own products, so an affiliated products, we want to make sure that we meet the needs of our customers.
We use this framework for how we're going to go to the business, acquire, anchor, bundle and extent. We see growth in 3 ways: One, selling products to new customers; two, selling additional products to our current customers as the need arises; and three, keeping our customers longer. Let me start with acquirer. Acquires had initial relationships with us. So whether you come in with specialized product or an auto product, we just getting to know you got in fact, we are pivoting to the company and trying to be less about policies and more about customers and households. We're currently in 1 in 10 households in the United States and we would like to double that in short order. So we're doing that through acquiring more and more customers and understanding their needs and then evolving as their needs evolve.
Anchor. Our anchor products are our auto and our home. If you trust us with those assets, we believe that our relationship is much deeper. I started today talking about the opportunity, the $300 billion, almost $300 billion opportunity in auto and home. Now that we have access to that and how more and more customers coming in either at home or auto, we know we can deepen that relationship. It's such an important piece of future Robinsons.
Bundle, that's what we're going to talk about today. Our bundle our Robinson's, our auto and home together, and just even a little bit of increased market share on the bundled part, really has that big impact on the bottom line.
Lastly, extent. We have been talking about retentions for some time and we have made a significant breakthrough. Last year, if you recall, I announced that I asked Andrew Quigg to lead a team of people to try to increase our retention by 50%. He's going to talk about that today but we're extraordinarily happy with our results.
So need stand is about talking any longer about customers, say, 1 month or even 1 year. It's about having customers for decades. In fact, one of the things of our customers after the first renewals are decade customers so we're pretty pleased with that. About 1 month or so ago, some of us went out to observe some focus groups of our customers. So we listened to Dianes with renters, Dianes with out renters. We're trying to get some insights. We're Minneapolis in Dallas and we listened to some decade customers and they came because they love their brand and they love their price so that makes sense. They stayed because over that decade or more time with us, they have some sort in service with a had a claim what they need to call in the ginger vehicle or deductible and they were extraordinarily happy with the service. But what we heard from both of the decade customer groups was something I think really insightful. People are asking, why are you going to state even if they stay? Yes, because I'm proud to be a Progressive customer and that really hit us and we heard that over and over again and so we're working on filing that feeling and having it happen earlier in someone's tenure, have the feel that pride Year 3, Year 4, so we can continue to extend that and increase our customers. And in fact, we're looking at different metrics at some point, we'll continue to have policy life expectancy but why wouldn't have customer life expectancy? So that's where we'll evolve as our customers evolve.
Ultimately, our goal, our vision to become consumers #1 choice in destination for auto and other insurance. The next 4 speakers are going to talk about how we're going to do that on both the auto side and John Barbagallo will talk about how he's going to do that on the commercial side.
So now I'd like to start and invite our Personal Lines president, Pat Callahan up to talk about agency growth, our product and our bundled competitiveness.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tricia. So last year, when we talked, I laid out 3 key strategic priorities for our personal lines business. Those were restoring growth in agencies, increasing our bundled penetration and ultimately advancing in product development cycle. I want
componenttext:
Thanks, Tricia. So last year, when we talked, I laid out 3 key strategic priorities for our personal lines business. Those were restoring growth in agencies, increasing our bundled penetration and ultimately advancing in product development cycle. I want to give you updates in all 3 and what we'll do is start with an overall view of the market from an overall channel and market size perspective.
As Tricia mentioned, U.S. personal auto and home is rapidly approaching a $300 billion market and when you look at the independent agency share of that, it's a little more than 1/3 or about $100 billion of home and auto premium. And despite the fact that the technology adoption has been rapidly increasing the growth rate for direct distribution of personal lines products, the independent agency channel continues to grow premium. And that's due in part of broad distribution of the footprints but also a great value proposition from a breadth of products offered and there's a breadth of choice available. When you look more specifically at the homeowners market in the U.S, it's about a $90 billion market and that's about 90% sold to agents, more than 40% through independent agents. And as the #1 writer of auto insurance through the independent agency channel, we believe we're incredibly well-positioned to leverage our strength in the channel, combined with ASI's property offerings, to become the #1 writer of auto and home insurance through the agency channel.
Last year, I told you that we restoring growth and agency with a top priority for myself and the lust of other folks within a Personal Lines organization. So today, I'm going to show you some information that after a business drop slightly into 2014 and barely recovered into 2015, we've turned that Agency business around from a size perspective. And at this point, our agency auto business as well as ASI's home owner business through independent agents have both never before been larger. And if we zoom in on what's driving that auto improvement, we'll primarily start with at new business apps. New business growth is the lifeline our lifeblood of a great organization like Progressive. And as you see on the screen, midway through 2015, we turned new business positive on a year-over-year basis within the agency channel. Our new business growth continues to be up in the double digits and 8 year-over-year basis ever since.
New business growth originates from 2 primary metrics. The first is demand, so quoting. The second is conversion and our improvements in the agency channel are driven just about by equal parts of both, which indicate to us: number 1, we have a more competitive product in market; but number 2, that more competitive product is inducing agents to come to us more frequently to meet the needs of our clients. An absolutely fantastic combination within the channel.
But to understand how competitive we are overall in this channel, the best benchmark that we can use is how well we're converting on comparative raters. So last year, shared with you that the majority of our agency of coats we'll start on the comparative platform. I just on the level comparative rating software, desktop applications and aging softness, they run a real-time risk by risk auction most all the carriers to participate within that agent's office. And then, you'll notice that similar to what we saw from a new apps perspective, we're seeing increasing new business from a converging perspective on comparative Raiders, to positive if it around the same time was on you business apps turn overall and continues to be up solving the double digits.
The exciting part about this for us though is competitive rates absolutely matter, but competitive rates are not sufficient to drive conversion in the agency channel. Because of the plethora of choices that agents have, you'll also have to have competitive service, competitive ease-of-use and ultimately, competitive compensation. So we believe comparative rate or conversion is a fantastic benchmark for us to truly understand how competitively we are overall in the agency marketplace.
Last year at this time, I also shared that we have just introduced HR 3, our latest auto product model and while the early results were encouraging, we run a couple of states and we're seeing significant growth overall from the product model. At this point, about 18 months later, I'm thrilled to share that, that growth continues to come in at expected levels but it's had because situated on the more preferred end of the spectrum. So our growth rates with Wrights and with Robinsons are significantly higher than they are in our other segments. These segments are absolutely foundational to how we went to the Destination Era and our product design and product development is helping us get there.
But we all know that Progressive is known for new business acquisitions. With a great job. We'll probably do the best job in the industry. But the reality of it is, sustainable premium growth doesn't just come from acquiring new customers. We have to retain them. And I'm pleased to share that when you look at retention from the agency channel, we see as after a dip in early 2015 through about the middle of the year, we've been increasing our agency policy life expectancy month-on-month ever since. And Andrew will talk a little bit more about more details about decomposing that but the drivers of that are twofold: #1, it's mixed. So our mix of new customers have improved. We refer to that as in nature but equal parts of improvement in our PLE are coming from experienced improvements and relationships within our customer relationship management organization. Those investments are paying off and Andrew will tell you a little bit more about that later.
What's particularly exciting to me though when I look at our retention improvements is to overlay our rate activity during the same period of time. So your orange bars are annualized rate change within the agency channel for each month during that same period. What you'll notice is during the period time that our retention was improving, we were raising rates, somewhere between 2%, 2.5% to 4%. And we do that to keep up with dreaded to make sure that we continue to deliver our target margins but the combination of being able to improve retention while also increasing rates indicates to us 2 things: number 1, market conditions are fantastic for growth in the agency channel and we are really really well-positioned; but number 2, given the plethora of choices that agents have to move business 2 when rates go up, the fact that our rate increases are sticking indicates to us we've got stronger relationships that are forming the agency channel and that's a critical element of our long-term destination success.
In terms of the trust basis business, and trust is really a difficult thing for us to measure unlike any of our other metrics. But look at actions as opposed to words to understand how we're performing from a customer perspective. Number 1, are agents trusting us by placing their better customers with us. The answer is yes. Number 2, are they trusting us to interact with those customers on a regular basis? The answer is yes. More agents are joining in marketing programs for additional protection solicitation, et cetera. And number 3, in a recent survey of thousands of independent agents. They responded that increasingly Progressive has all the products to meet the needs of their preferred customers and more of those agents responded that they're placing their preferred customers with us. The turnaround agency channel was driven by a combination of product and stronger relationship building and we fully expect that the momentum that we established today will this turnaround while tearing into our second priority which is bundled penetration.
Growing bundled penetration is the key performance indicator of our Destination Era. Making progress selling both home and auto to our combined customers is essential to our long-term success. And the things you need to drive bundled penetration are number 1, available and competitive property insurance; number 2, available in competitive preferred auto rates; number 3, the systems tools and experiences that enables customers and agents to find, quote, buy and ultimately own a Progressive policy or a Progressive bundle. We'll stay with the agency channel for now and talk about where we're headed from a bundled penetration perspective.
Last year this year we were in the process of deploying is less poverty products countrywide. Since we last talked, we've added 9 states and by the end of this year, we'll be in 39 states representing about 95% of U.S. homeowners, great coverage for where we are in the rollout. We go to market from an agency perspective with our product through 2 tiers of agencies. Those 2 tiers of agencies are Progressive advantage agencies, Progressive Home Advantage agencies and our Platinum agencies. 2 tiers Progressive Home advantage, literally more distributed, they are our original property agencies and Platinum is much higher tier, more highly selective tariff agents and much stronger partnership with this. I shared with you last year that Platinum is a brand-new program that we're introducing last summer that combined consumer benefits of annual policies, more competitive rates through multi-policy discounts and agent benefits, such as easier-to-use systems and higher compensation. We continue to deploy the Platinum program as well. Platinum by the end of this year will be in 34 states, which represent about 80% of U.S. homeowners and because preferred auto and property availability are prereqs to the Platinum rollout, Platinum will always trail that we will love than a property products. But overall, we intend to continue pushing on a countrywide basis so we have full deployment of preferred auto, available property and Platinum on a national basis.
But with Platinum, it's less about the states that we're in and much more about the agencies that we're in within those states. So over the last year, we've identified selective and ultimately unboarded more than 1,000 agencies into our Platinum program. Based on those agencies, access to preferred customers, their bundled goldenseal processes within the agencies and their willingness to commit the placing significant portion of their bundled volume with Progressive. But to be clear, Platinum rollout will be a metered rollout. Platinum has a scarcity and a scarcely distributed offering. So agents will be actively managed by our sales reps to ensure they're using the Platinum program and understand it and using it for bundled business within their agency. So we will continue to grow Platinum but we will grow Platinum as agents are using it effectively in market.
I also shared last year that because of ease-of-use for bundled quoting is a key element of our Platinum offering. We were starting to build a new Platinum quoting program. And earlier this year, we launched Platinum quoting, which brings to the agents desktop for the first time, bundled quoting of Progressive auto and ASI's home, which enables the agent to ultimately save time, share data entry screens and external data fill and have more competitive messaging around the bundled economics available to the agent and making it easier for them to message those bundled savings to the customer. Now to be clear, this is a pilot, it's in 3 states today. We learned a bunch to date, we continue to learn from the pilot and ultimately will build those enhancements indoor quoting systems over time.
But the $1 billion question all of our minds and exactly all of your minds is, is black Platinum working? We've attacked the preferred agency a few times before and we've learned from those attacks. We've learned from those opportunities that ultimately, for us to introduce a brand-new preferred offering into some of the best agencies in an incredibly competitive independent agency channel, we would have to change agent behavior, which we all know isn't simple and frankly it take time. So to understand with Platinum was working, we look at the 2015 cohort of Platinum agents. Those were appointed as but that I'm agents June 2015, liquidator the class of 2015, if you will. And we looked at 2 key performance metrics for that group of agencies whether the bid the rest of our property insurance agencies. What you're seeing in the screeners 2 lines, the blue line is our Platinum them agencies, the orange slanderous RPG agencies and the metric here is preferred auto production. While you know this but in those lines, there's #1, the blueline starts above the orange line, not surprisingly, more productive agencies were selected to be Platinum in the first place. But it looks that after the vertical red light, this increase in separation for in perspective between our Platinum agencies and are non-Platinum other property agencies.
So this continues into our second key performance metric and that's new business home and auto bundles you'll see exactly the same pattern. Blue, Platinum agents started above our pH agencies and the gap continues to widen as our sales reps message to benefit Platinum, are agents that are understand to benefit the Platinum and for their customers based to experience some of the benefits that come from by interval Platinum agencies. The gap between that blue and orange line is what we referred to as a Platinum difference. And that Platinum difference not just present with the agents reported during 2015. If you look at the entire network of more than 1,000 of Platinum agencies compared to a Platinum property agencies. You'll see that our Platinum agency plant is responsible for creating more than 3x of the number of bundles per agent per week then are not Platinum agencies which absolutely tells us that Platinum is working.
What you'll also notice on this graph though is the trend is upward, anywhere improving over time, none was bounced around from the month but we're on an upward trend. And the deadline on the screen indicates rent we expect a program to build the from a success perspective. You'll notice we're not there and that you have exist but would know what we're going to do to close that gap. The primary driver of that is a bundled competitiveness.
We're not surprisingly, when we relaunch our programs, we started collecting data from the market as to where we were competitive and we're not competitive. And the great thing is with 1,000 agencies, using their quoting systems to call it ASI properly in Progressive auto, with a data under BR and when we our next keen. Our next conversion as a primary metric in the latest is that represent about 1/3 of our premium. We're highly competitive in the my light auto, the my line home and on the bundle for an individual risk. And those agencies, our focus is to sale of our customers but looking forward, the leader for home, selling out if they're looking for auto, selling auto or try to sell them to bundle because we are highly competitive.
However, in about 2/3 of the country right now, we're highly competitive what Madeleine home our modeling auto but not yet as competitive on the bundle for individual risks. This shouldn't come as much surprise given we had a highly successful model light auto business to be combined with highly successful Madeleine home business and the overlap between the 2 isn't quite where we need to be. But the bottom line is we know exactly what needs to be done and we're collecting a ton of data that enables us to map out how to integrate our products more closely to make sure that we're more competitive at the individual risk on a country wide basis.
So for us, the momentum that we saw as we were bringing our agency turnaround ultimately in the bundled competitiveness, combined with the infrastructure investments we continue to make in he agency channel and the early success of what we're seeing from about their perspective gives us a ton of confidence to where we are absolutely the right track from a bundled penetration perspective and very, very well-positioned to attack that $100 billion independent agency home and auto opportunity.
With that, said, we have another highly successful auto distribution channel and that's direct. So I want to update you on where we are from a bundled competitiveness perspective within the direct channel. To be a direct customer destination for auto and other insurance, we not only need to have all the parts we need throughout their lifetime but they have to be aware of them and understand that we have them available before they have a lighter than the triggers demand for that product. So they come to us first as opposed to shopping and market. We generate awareness for products with a customer's and 3 primary ways. Mass media advertising. The reach is not only our current customers but also reaches future customers. Point-of-sale messaging and this is both in our sales systems as well as our servicing systems, so both our current customers and potential customers will visit to get a quote understand the breadth of products available and economic benefits of buying through us.
And finally, targeted marketing, we have a ton of my line customers, that we are now offering the bundled package and the complementary product, to messaging and savings and ease of use benefits of bringing more of those products to Progressive overtime.
This awareness investments coupled with a general shift in consumer buying trends toward direct and some internal messaging that gets our employee's taking holistically about protecting our customers household needs continues to drive up demand for direct property insurance, both online, on the phones with current customers and with future customers. But with demand increasing demand for the wreck property products crates no value unless we can meet that demand with adequate supply. And frankly, in early 2015, our ability to meet the demand for Direct Property was less than what we wanted it to be. Only about 4 or 5 customers coming to us for Direct Property could even get a quote. Part of that is just endemic with the property insurance business. Unlike Progressive, there's virtually no property writers who have similar or broad acceptability. Property writers have a relatively mixed focus and some a not accept 20%, 30%, 40% of available risks. That's an unacceptable outcome for our direct customers. So what we've done all the time is work, #1, with our carrier partners that expand accessibility and improve rallying of traffic online and to our partner call centers to improve availability of the recording. So it's particularly exciting of this chart is the yellow line. the yellow line is our competitive advantage agency which is our in-house agency that sells multiple products from a property perspective across multiple property partners. Over the last 1.5 year, we've made significant investments to expand the footprint of that agency by adding 14 states and adding more than 100 state and carrier combinations in order to drive up availability of this, of our property products. At this point, we can meet the needs of about 95% of current or future customers who contact our agency. And we believe that agency model is a superior shopping experience for anyone shopping direct-to-consumer property insurance because it combines the technology enabled ease-of-use of a direct writer with the breadth and depth of an independent agency. We believe strongly in that model and we continue to invest to expand capabilities within our Progressive Advantage Agency.
In the last 18 months, we've more than doubled staffing and when calls come in, we route an increase percentage of those to the agency to the point that at this point, we've more than tripled the sales over the last 18 months through the agency. We will continue to invest in that space and continue to use this superior business model to delight our direct customers and from a bundled penetration perspective. But for us, bundling is not just about home and auto. It's also about home renters and auto. So in our world, we enjoy an advantage position with younger, simpler needs, auto insurance customers, many of whom don't yet own a home. So having a renters insurance available for those customers enables us: Number 1, to establish our property insurance relationship with customers and to be able to meet a broader need of those customers earlier in their insurance shopping journey. Life of Insurance will never be a massive business for us. It's only about a $4 billion market. But for us, it is a strategic investment. As renters and insurance is absolutely a goodly property product towards the coming of bundled home and customer with us. We have evidence that those who bundle renters and auto with us are significantly more likely to keep their auto with us and convert that renters to homeowners policy if and when they eventually buy a home. So from a graduating Diane perspective, this is a strategic play for us and one we continue to invest in over time.
We are absolutely thrilled that the acceleration of our penetration from a bundling perspective within our direct book of business. Today, more than 1 million direct customers trust us to provide property and protection and the key performance metrics for our Direct Property business increasing cold starts, bundled new apps and bundled pets are all up more than 20% on a year-over-year basis. And with investments we continue to make to drive demand and then, meet that demand with ample supply and great experiences, we have every confidence we will continue to accelerate bundled penetration within the direct book of business.
The third priority I shared with you last year is it continues to advance or science of risks and segmentation. Customer segmentation, matching rate to risk and pricing accuracy are in our DNA and absolutely a key source of competitive advantage for Progressive. It's been that way for decades and what of the things that truly differentiates and distinguishes our offering. As we look to invest in rate accuracy and pricing segmentation, we recognize that the value creates through more competitive new business pricing which lowers our customer acquisition costs on the fixed advertising base. It increases our retention even if customers shop and get to play similar coverage at a similar or lower price and it creates that adverse election within the marketplace, 1 the trifecta of opportunity for Progressive. So when we think about the product of element space, we focus on 3 areas, the first is rate accuracy, the second is coverages and the third is improving customer to drive policy life expectancy. These builds, bundles are these enhancements in the product model and deploy them like building blocks, stacked on top of all the segmentation that existed in the prior model.
Our pipeline from a roadmap perspective is absolutely robust from a product development standpoint.  We're currently on A3 in the majority of our states. A3 was designed to be more competitive on preferred households and will the product customers. You already heard how that's performing in market. We are thrilled with how it's working.
A4 is deploying currently. Tomorrow morning, you'll be our 7th state elevating for A4 and 8 4 brings with it more stable rates for our renewal customers as well as advanced segmentation based on building, claim experience and vehicle history. 8 4 5 is 8 4 with some additional protection for transportation network company drivers, Progressive customers who happen to work for Uber and lift. And finally, 8 5 which is under development right now and will launch in early 2018, will bring with it much more competitive rates for households with people as well as -- I'm not going to tell you what else us in this, you're going to come back next our to learn more about that. But rest assured, we're not taken our foot off the accelerator from a product development perspective and then, to continue to lead from a segmentation perspective. But that segment vision of the world creates no value if we can't get it to market quickly. And while we've always been known for our nimbleness and ability to deploy our products to market quickly, we recognized from a core value perspective that excellence is doing things better today than we did yesterday and we continue to invest to advance our speed to market. So in the last 24 months, there's been a joint research and development and ITP reengineering our process, product development and product deployment and since we last talked in May, they have been able to double the annualized rate with which we can deploy our product innovation into the market place. So what that means is when we talk in May, we have 3 states on a 3. Today, we have 32 states. As of tomorrow, we'll have 7 states on A4. When we talk next year, we'll have 38 states on A4 and A5 will be spun up just about to hit the market. This is a lethal combination of product innovation and speed to market enables us to widen our lead over the competition. And when we look to assess how well we're doing relative to the competition, we start by looking at some industry data. The industry data you're seeing on the screen is loss in LAE for PCI, essentially about 2/3 of the market, 9 of the Top 10 carriers and the orange line and then, Progressive in the blueline. What you will notice is that the environmental activities, the economic recovery, gas prices, severity on low pricing cars due to safety equipment, trend in the industry has been declining since the middle of 2012. You'll also notice that the blueline, the progress of Lawson LAE, we've been competing and that exact same environment and the reality of it is results have been rock solid. The difference between these 2 lines is products segmentation. It's our ability to better understand what risks we're ensuring and better sort out which ones are high-cost from low-costs. What that means in the marketplace is those in the orange line, the rest of the market as their loss costs declining and they don't know which risks are driving there was lost cost up, and when they raise base rates and with a rate base rates, our best customers and their book of business shop and they can often find a lower price with companies like us that are better segmented.  We're on the cycle over and over enough times and they're left with residual risks that they're still under price balance and press the dramatically high than the market on any of the better risks that we ensure. What it also means though for us is today, we enjoy about a 10 point gap in loss LAE related to the market and when you combine that with a technology enabled expense gap, specifically in the agency channel, what it enables us to do is combine incredibly competitive pricing end market, which drives the growth of the business with wider underwriting profit margins than the overall industry, delivering on our profit targets. A great combination for an insurance business.
Now I also told you last year, that emerging data sources for an opportunity as opposed to a threat to Progressive. And since making our majority investment in ASI or ARX, we've been building a massive data set of home and auto risk characteristics in home and auto loss characteristics. What this has enabled us to do is improve model accuracy, identifying new segmentation and reduce our rating costs. An early example of how we're leveraging this data set was a waiting variable that was highly predictive of home loss frequency. To the tune of about a 30% difference in pure premium. As a way to identify that if I quickly jumped on it and deployed at the market. So it's providing a segmentation risks as a bundled household that they wouldn't normally have had absent the joining of this data. And to be frank, we are just getting started to get into this massive data set and fully expect that the joint R&D team between ASI and Progressive will leverage this treasure trove of information to identify new ways to assess and ultimately, price and improve rate accuracy for our household bundled pricing.
Last year, I shared with you some fairly aggressive goals for our overall business with the turnaround in our Agency business as well as a great performance from our direct business, coupled with the investments we're making to increase model penetration across both our direct and our Agency business, robust but development pipeline, or future segmentation enhancements and the fastest speed to market on top of our ailing industry, I am absolutely confident that we are incredibly well-positioned to become consumers #1 choice in destination for auto and other insurance.
With that, I'll bring John Sauerland now to talk about Snapshot and data management.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. I have the pleasure of speaking to you today on sheer topics. The first half of the section will be our attention, tell you about improving momentum to see them attention. And then, on the second half of the section, provide an overview o
componenttext:
Thank you, John. I have the pleasure of speaking to you today on sheer topics. The first half of the section will be our attention, tell you about improving momentum to see them attention. And then, on the second half of the section, provide an overview of our customer marketing initiative and then, I'll describe advanced analytics as John Sauerland alluded to.
So first off, I wanted to just greater rate of preferred retention measure which is policy life for retention or purely. PLE is the average length of time we expect the new policy to stay with Progressive. We calculate PLE by first calculating our retention to K curve and then, we take the area under the curve to get our PLE statistics. That retention decay curve can be cultivated multiple ways depending on the trade-off and responsiveness versus the stability of that we see here. Our standard measure is to use 12 months for each point along that curve. That is our trailing 12 PLE that we always recorded out. We also calculate a trailing 3 PLE starting in 2014. The trailing 3 PLE uses 3 -- the most recent 3 months along that retention to get curves. So it's more responsive to more recent observations. Specific notes on the PLE calculation. The first 60 much represent actual data that we recently observed and between months 60 and 300, we used an extrapolation and we've seen all policies after 300 months, which is a conservative assumption. We think the PLE is accurate for a number of reasons and I'll highlight one of those today. We think it removes any tenure of bias. So if we use simple retention rates, as our book of business ages, all else being equal, we think we'd see higher retention rates and that would be although that retention curve getting shifted. So using those the PLE calculation remove any 10pyear bias from our statistics.
So with that, background, I wanted to give you an update on the current progress with trailing 12 PLE. I'm happy to report that we've seen very positive PLE growth in 2016. We are up 6% year-over-year. 6%, 6% year-over-year, there we go. This is a large increase since 2009 and as Tricia said on our last quarterly conference call, for every one month of PLE, we see $1.5 billion in additional lifetime or for the company. We're also seeing similar percentage increases within our agency channel and in our direct channel and the rest is at an all-time high. What we're really pleased with the overall momentum we see, we're even more pleased with what we see in the Robinsons in the Destination Era. For our Robinsons, PLE is up 17% over the past 3 years. And the past 12 months, we're up 9%. So just great momentum that we're seeing with the Robinsons. As Tricia alluded to earlier, the Robinsons are now 3x greater and 3.5x greater than our Sams for PLE. 
We'll also be adjusting the PLE calculation in the coming months. We haven't updated extrapolation for a while, and we're seeing better retention in that of the PLE curve than we've seen historically. And so when we update the PLE calculation, overall PLE go up by more than -- by about 2%. And for our Robinsons it will be given higher. Our Robinsons are disproportionately represented in the tale of the PLE curves. That means it will even more opportunity for Robinsons. We'll be able to acquire their more aggressively, and we'll be able to bundle our current customers more aggressively. So far speaking inclusively about the trailing 12 PLE, but I want to go back to the trailing 3 that I talked about in the opening. If we think about the difference between the trailing 3 and the trailing 12 PLE is the unrealized momentum in our PLE data. And we're very pleased with what we see here. For total auto, the trading 3 PLE is up 8% year-over-year. For the trailing 12 PLE, it's up 6%. So we think we have about 2 points of unrealized momentum within our PLE. As you can see across all of our segments, the trading 3 PLE is higher year-over-year than the trailing 12, so we feel like we have a lot of momentum. But the difference before Robinsons. For Robinsons, we think we have about 4 points of momentum that we haven't yet realized. I'm going to stop here and just talk about the goal that Trish outlined for us in 2015. Trish has challenged us an increased retention by 50%. We think we can achieve this in 3 ways. First, we believe we can change our. mix. In the destination era, we think we can change our mix to more preferred customers and new business. Pat outlined some of the strategies we have there. In addition to changing mix, we think we can improve our price competitiveness relative to the competition. Pat showed the slide where we have increasing Agency PLE while overall rates are being increased. And third, we believe we can improve the customer experience. We think we can nurture our customers to stay with progressive longer, and I'll spend some time on that in the next section. We think this path to a 50% increase to a more preferred segments. We see more opportunities with our more preferred segments increased retention. And then as the mix of our business changes, we believe we'll have better overall goal of and increasing retention by 50%. 
I want to switch gears here and start talking about the nurture side of things. But I want to pause and just talk about data for a minute, specifically how are using data for consumer experience. We see a virtual cycling in our pricing. I started off in Product management. This was a big part of our roles. In pricing, we see that when we acquired customers, we are paying their data. And with that data, we can derive segmentation and insights and improve our pricing, which allows us to acquire more customers, which gives us more data, which gives us better segmentation, a virtual cycle exist within our pricing. We think the same virtual cycle exists with our customers in customer experience, specifically with our customers we -- customers and then we interact with them. With interactions generate data and that data provides insight and ideas in segmentation that allows us increased retention, which allows us to have our customers. And more customers provides more interactions and more data and we get a virtual cycle here with an customer experience as well. And in the destination era, as we get more products, we think been even faster, more products, more interactions, which means more data. So as we invest in the best ever with equally have even more predictive data to use with our customers. We do that background because leveraging data as part of the larger initiative that we working on here at progressive. In the 2015 Investor Relations meeting, Glenn saw that we need to be a good customer marketing as we are at consumer marketing. And so we put a joint team together from our customer relationship management organization and corporate marketing, and that team is working on this customer marketing initiatives. There are 4 pillars that we've talked about with the customer marketing initiatives. The first is that we want to improve our customer knowledge. We want to such predictive data because we can for our customers, that we know the experience that are going through. After that, we want to improve our customer engagement. There's 2 parts this. We want to improve the practices that they go through, and we want to segment those customers better. The third pillar is interfaces. As we've come up with segmentation and processes, we need flexible interfaces that can deliver those to our customers. And then finally, we want to brand these interfaces for our customers. Jeff talked about this last year so I won't spend time on this year. So we want to have the branding that resonates with our the customers as they interact with us.

But probably 4 or 5 years ago, we started around ensuring that we were bringing new business those intent it was to enter and not otherwise. And I think that helped us a lot. But higher than ever, you can improve profitability to raising rates or underwriting segments in Commercial Lines has been very faster react in turning on the underwriting more necessary, and they're now reacting very quickly in getting rates and expect to have this rates up about 9% by the end of the year.

headline: Progressive Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you for those out of counter, who came in, and welcome to Progressive's 2016 Investor Relations Day. We're glad to have you. I think you're all familiar with the Safe Harbor statements, and if not, there's also a copy in y
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody. Thank you for those out of counter, who came in, and welcome to Progressive's 2016 Investor Relations Day. We're glad to have you. I think you're all familiar with the Safe Harbor statements, and if not, there's also a copy in your materials as a reference guide.
So this particular Investor Relations meeting represents a really big change. For many, many years, Glenn Renwick was the host these meetings, in fact, I think he started them. Last week, Glenn celebrated his 30th anniversary with Progressive, of which more than half of that he was our CEO and President. During his tenure as CEO, he tripled the company in size. So by most record books you would say, that is phenomenal, and it is. But it's not just that. It's not just what Glenn did, it's how he did it. Always making sure to instill in us that desire to win but doing it in the right way, always following our core values. He always would set the bar higher every year for all of us. And then he won't walk away, he would help us get over, and that is really his legacy. So Glenn, on behalf of the 30,000 Progressive people, our shareholders and the customers we're privileged to serve, thank you for well being Progressive.
Okay, enough about Glenn. I thought what I do to start off is just remind you of our segments. So we outlined these several years ago when we first started talking about our Destination Era strategy. So I'll just briefly go over those. The focus today will be on the Robinsons, and we're really excited to talk to you about what we have done since he last met you in May 2015.
So Sam. Sam is a segment we grow up with, that we call him inconsistently insured. He is who Progressive -- he put us on the map, and we call him nonstandard. He cares about rates, doesn't stay very long but he could come back. We love Sam. We want to write all the Sam's we can possibly write as long as it reaches our profitability goal.
Diane. Diane is a big part of the Destination Era. We've talked in the past about her being a future Robinson. Diane is an auto customer, and she rents. So she may have renters insurance with us, and what we hope is that as her needs evolve and she buys a home, gets married, that we evolve with her. It's the notion of Diane graduating to be a Robinson. She's our largest customer base, so the opportunity there is immense.
The Wrights. The Wrights are unbundled auto and home. So they have Progressive home and someone else's auto. Again, we love the Wrights. We see them as future Robinsons because we hope that if they decide to shop their homeowners, they come with us and become a Robinson.
The Robinsons. That's what today is all about and what's a Destination Era is all about, the auto home bundle. The Robinsons are 40% of the market. So the opportunity here is really great, and we are really proud of how the momentum we've had in the last 18 months in particular in obtaining Robinsons.
Before we get started, what I thought I do as a new CEO is step back and just take stock of some objectives and some fundamentals that will stay the same during my tenure of things that might evolve. And clearly, with Glenn's leadership, I was a part of the team that developed the strategy around the Destination Era. So to make a turn and do something differently would make sense. I believe in this model, the execution has been great and I'm excited about our future. But things do evolve as a team as we know more.
Let me start with our first and most important objective, profit. We want to make at least $0.04 of underwriting profit of every $1 of premium. $0.96 is essential to our culture. You're actually sitting in an auditorium that's called Studio 96, so you know how integrated it is into everything we do. It continues to be our most important objective, and that won't change. There is, however, an added dimension with the auto home bundle. We're looking at how 2 independent margins can be optimized for that package. So while the $0.96 will stay the same, how it will be derived will absolutely evolve.
Growth. We want to grow as fast as we can with 2 constraints: one, the profit objective I just outlined; and two, our ability to service our customers. That second one is really important to us. So about 18 months ago, we had our A3 model on the streets, it was working, we were getting a lot more preferred customers. We also saw the opportunity when some of our competition pulled back to spend more on advertising, specifically, in the digital option. So we knew at that point we had a lot of opportunities to grow. We made a decision at that time to hire well in advance of need. So from the claims organization as well as our customer relationship management organization, both on the audit side and the commercial side. And I'm so pleased that we did that, because we did get that growth. We got that preferred growth. And in addition, we have things that happened that we didn't necessarily planned for in the form of catastrophes. So we've been able to service our customers no matter if it was a CAT or a regular -- just increase in losses based on growth.
It is sort of a rule here Progressive that whether you're on the claims side or the product side, if you think people were growing too fast, you absolutely have to raise your hand and say, "No more growth. We can't do this. And we had to do that in the past." I'm so delighted to say that this year we didn't have to do that because we prepared and hired in advance of need. So when I think about growth and profit and that balance, year-to-date with August being the most recent time frame with 96.2% [ph] net room premium growth. If we ended the year today, this is a phenomenal year, especially with the business that we've been putting on the book. I'm extraordinarily happy. If we were the same margin at 96.2% and had 4% growth with the same set of circumstances, I wouldn't be as happy. If we were at 88% with 0% growth, I wouldn't be happy. I'm very, very pleased with our growth. It really is sort of a perfect storm. So we have this new business, and we talked and talked at the conference calls about the sort of new business pacts that can have, when our combined ratio was higher in that first term. And we had that coming at us, and then we had CAT. This year, we have -- on our CR, 3 points of our combined ratio are in the form of CAT, which is compared to this time last year, about 1.5%. In fact, last month with Louisiana storm, it was over 4 points of our CR. So you can't plan for CAT. Believe me, I'm watching Matthew closely. You can't plan for CAT. Well, you can't plan for CAT, how you react to those CAT. I am extraordinarily pleased with how we have reacted specifically the Louisiana storm. So about 3 weeks ago, a group of us flew down and spent some time in Lafayette and Baton Rouge, Louisiana to make sure our employees were okay, our customers were okay, and I was just amazed. I was amazed that our CAT team, who went down there and just made sure they took it upon themselves to get our customers back on their feet. We literally had employees who were laying in bed, and they found out their home was flooded when they put their foot in water. Yet, they came to work that day to help our customers. In fact, as of yesterday, we have closed 96% of those flood claims, which is really amazing because they're complex claims, mostly total losses. So again, I'm so amazed that what we're able to do and what we're able to do. And what we are ready with whatever happens with Matthew. As of today, we have a plan, and we'll figure it out. That's what we do.
So for me, again, just to wrap up in that part, profit and growth, very happy, very proud, especially with how we've been increasing our preferred business, the Robinsons, and we're going to talk a lot about that today.
I thought I'd take just a stab at some of the financial fundamentals. So it won't change. I think they work with our business plan. We want to continue to balance operating risk with the risk of investing in financing activities, in order to have sufficient capital to support our growth. So that's the overview. On the operating side, we want to maintain pricing and reserving discipline. So when we talk about our pricing, we talk about managing targets. We talk about targets at the lowest definition. So whether it's on the agency and direct side, product state, we really segment our targets. And that's another reason why I'm so positive about this new business because we look at the new business coming in and say, "Is it at or below targets? Great, that's going to run off profitably." So we're excited about that.
We want to have a premium to surplus at or below state of minimum requirement. So on auto, that's a 3:1 and about half of that for home. And on the loss reserving side, we want to make sure loss reserves are adequate and developed with a minimal variant. Year-to-date, very proud of that. We are pretty close but are limited on the favorable side, which is the side you want to be on. On investing side, we want to maintain a liquid, diversified and high-quality portfolio. We manage our investments on a total return basis, which is very consistent with how we report our comprehensive income. And on the risk side, we want to manage interest rate, credit, prepayment, concentration and extension risk. Lastly, on the financing side, we want to maintain sufficient capital to support the insurance operations. That's measured by maintaining a debt below 30% of total capital of book value. So we're just slightly over 28% right now, and that's after issuing $500 million worth of debt in August. We want to neutralize dilution from equity-based compensation in the year of issuance, and we do that by repurchasing shares. And finally, we were investing capital and expanding the business when it meets our objectives. A perfect example of this is our acquisition of ARX. We didn't necessarily feel like we had to have a homeowners company. What we felt is we had to have access to that addressable market. That is a $300 billion market with auto and home. We needed to have access, and it just so happened that we've been working with the company that we've had a high amount of respect for, that had a very similar culture and so is a perfect relationship to start. So we're very pleased with our use of capital in acquiring ARX. Any use of underleveraged capital, we will buy back shares or issue dividends, whether special or variable.
So let's get to the 96, since we are slightly over at this point. I want to walk you through kind of how we look at it. This is just a basic refresher. So everybody gets to 96, all of our customers at some point get there, but sometimes in vastly different ways. On the direct side, you can see we run a much higher combined ratio in that first term. That's based on the fact that we have a little higher loss cost and some underwriting cost, but most of all, we front-load all of our acquisitions cost on the direct side in that first term.
On the Asian side, we have a little bit more losses, a little bit more underwriting, but it's a relatively fixed commission expense, so much lower in the first term. So let me take you through on the direct side, 2 ends of the spectrum. You have Sam and the Robinsons. So you can see the same dynamic. They both rendered a loss in the first term. But what is not evident in our monthly reporting or even our quarterly reporting is the fact that there's very high-retaining business, the Robinsons, can stay 3 times, actually, more than 3 times longer than the Sam, are expanding our invisible balance sheet. So bringing on more of those Robinsons, really build the intrinsic value of Progressive.
Here's a basic income statement, and it's directly accurate. So if you look at it again, the Sam and Robinsons, you look at revenue. Clearly, the Robinsons are higher, based on the fact that they stay longer and they have higher average written premium. If you look at the operating expenses, which of course are losses, LAE and expense ratio, you quickly notice that neither of these are equal to 96. Those numbers represent the nominal value of the cash flow, so they're under 96. Our lifetime target, 96 combined ratio, for our direct business, we discount the cash flows to recover our acquisition expenses. So that will be different in different segments depending on how long they stay. The difference between those of course is our underwriting income. And then there's other income that we have, both on the investment side for both Sam and Robinsons and the commissions side for just the Robinsons. So whether it's affiliate partner, like ASI, or other unaffiliated homeowners owners, we get commissions when we have those bundles. So as you can see, the value of a Robinson, a pretax value, is over 4x that of a Sam. Again, we love Sam as long as we can make money on them, but the value of a Robinson is extraordinary, and the fact that we have grown Robinson substantially in this last 18 months really does grow the value, the intrinsic value of Progressive.
So for years, we have shared with you the invisible balance sheet. We talked last year about unearned lifetime earned premium. So when we think about business coming on board, we look at new apps, for example. So in this year for Wrights and Robinson, we've grown new apps 30% and 40%, respectively. That's pretty great. We look at average written premium. Our average premium has come up across all segments. And then we look at PLE. This is [indiscernible] to be a spoiler alert for Andrew section that we finally have made a breakthrough on retention and PLE. So it us -- those 3 things are really exciting. So we thought we'd share with you one other metric that we look at internally, that we call ULUP, Unearned Lifetime Underwriting Process. So you'll see that the colors represent a segment so green for the Robinsons, pink for the Wrights, et cetera. On the Y axis, you see ULUP in millions, and on the X axis, you'll see the time frame with which we're looking out. So right when we started to grow, right around March of last year to our most recent data point. As you can see, the majority of our segments are growing substantially in ULUP, which, again, is building that intrinsic value. In fact, the Robinsons are growing over 60%.
The chart underneath shows all of the segments year-over-year growth in ULUP, and again, all are growing, so you can see the Robinsons are growing at a really quick clip. That's exciting for us.
I'm going to shift gears now and talk about how important understanding the Destination Era is to the 30,000 Progressive people that work on getting our customers indoor and making sure we nurture them along the way. We look at it in terms of different frameworks. This is a framework we use, called our strategic pillars. So let me talk about the first one, our culture. Our culture is so important, and it's not something you can really adequately describe unless you spent time at Progressive. It's not something you're going to see on a spreadsheet. But it is really special, and it's really different, and we know it's a competitive advantage. It's really at the root of what I started to talk about, and that is doing the right thing. And we want to win but you always want to do the right thing, and it's really rooted in our core values. I am privileged to speak at every new hire class, actually, with that with one Monday with couple hundred new claims reps. And my sole topic is our core value. I talk about 15 or 20 minutes, use some examples and then let them ask questions. It's so important to me for them on their first day or their first week or their second week to know what an important part that is of Progressive, our value.
Earlier this year, many of us went out to celebrate a milestone at Progressive, $20 billion in earned premium. And we got out face-to-face with over half of our employees, over 15,000 people, just to celebrate and say thank you for all that you do, and then of course talk about the next milestone and the next milestone, and it was really rewarding, and that again is a big part of our culture.
Our brand. We want to be the brand people want. So whether it's awareness or preference or consideration, those things are important but what we really want is to be able to, when people buy an insurance product from Progressive, that they feel confident that they've made a right decision and continue to feel confident as we service them and add more and more policies. We want to spend money on consumer marketing and customer marketing. We've talked often about how we want to have our customer marketing be as savvy as our consumer marketing. Andrew Quigg is going to talk a little bit about that today, but we continue to resource that as it is an important part of nurturing our customers.
Competitive prices. In a business with small margins, this is very important to us. It's really all around segmentation. You're going to hear a lot about that today. So John Sauerland is going to talk about our continued evolution with UBI and our segmentation, and how important that variable is. Pat Callahan is going to talk about segmentation and the product model that we continue to elevate as well as our bundled competitiveness. Andrew Quigg will talk about segmentation on the customer part and using data to get out in front of our customers to know what they need, when they need them. So this is really important part of our -- really central to things that we do is segmentation. We'll continue to hone in on that.
Another part about competitive prices is really having a competitive loss structure. So on the claim side, we continued to have -- try to have that near-perfect balance of cost and quality, so pushing down LAE, while pushing up accuracy, and we're doing a fantastic job. On the expense side, we look at what we call nonacquisition expense ratio. So we continue to try to push that down, be more efficient and then give that pricing advantage to our customers in the form of competitive prices.
And the last pillar is meeting the broader needs of our customers what products do they want, when do they wanted, how do they want to shop. We want to make sure we can have personalized service and products for each of our customers. So if you want to buy through an agent, get service online or through a chat, we want to make sure if it fits your needs, we are there for you. We want to pick up the phone and say, "Yes, we can do that, absolutely." And whether or not we do that through our own products or an affiliated products, we want to make sure we meet the needs of our customers.
We use this framework for how we're going to grow the business, acquire, anchor, bundle and extend. We see growth in 3 ways: one, selling products to new customers; two, selling additional products to our current customers as the need arises; and three, keeping our customers longer.
